commands.name: unset <component-pattern>
commands.description: un-sets an env from components that were previously set by "bit env set" or by a component template
commands.extendedDescription:
keep in mind that this doesn't remove envs that are set via variants.
in only removes envs that appear in the .bitmap file, which were previously configured via "bit env set".
the purpose of this command is to reset previously assigned envs to either allow variants configure the env or use the base node env.
you can use a `<pattern>` for multiple component ids, such as `bit env unset "org.scope/utils/**"`.
use comma to separate patterns and '!' to exclude. e.g. 'ui/**, !ui/button'
use '$' prefix to filter by states/attributes, e.g. '$deprecated', '$modified' or '$env:teambit.react/react'.
always wrap the pattern with single quotes to avoid collision with shell commands.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

name: capsule
description: manage capsules
extendedDescription:
a capsule is a directory containing the component code, isolated from the workspace.
normally, capsules are created during the build process, the component files are copied and the packages are installed
via the configured package-manager. the purpose is to compile/test them in isolation to make sure they will work for
other users after publishing/exporting them.

name: pattern <pattern>
description: list the component ids matching the given pattern
extendedDescription:
this command helps validating a pattern before using it in other commands.
NOTE: always wrap the pattern with quotes to avoid collision with shell commands. depending on your shell, it might be single or double quotes.
a pattern can be a simple component-id or component-name. e.g. 'ui/button'.
a pattern can be used with wildcards for multiple component ids, e.g. 'org.scope/utils/**' or '**/utils/**' to capture all org/scopes.
to enter multiple patterns, separate them by a comma, e.g. 'ui/*, lib/*'
to exclude, use '!'. e.g. 'ui/**, !ui/button'
the matching algorithm is from multimatch (@see https://github.com/sindresorhus/multimatch).

to filter by a state or attribute, prefix the pattern with "$". e.g. '$deprecated', '$modified'.
list of supported states: [new, modified, deprecated, deleted, snappedOnMain, softTagged, codeModified, localOnly].
to filter by multi-params state/attribute, separate the params with ":", e.g. '$env:teambit.react/react'.
list of supported multi-params states: [env].
to match a state and another criteria, use " AND " keyword. e.g. '$modified AND teambit.workspace/** AND $env:teambit.react/react'.

examples.description: matches all components
matches components with any scope-name and the "ui" namespace. e.g. "ui/button" but not "ui/elements/button"
matches components whose namespace starts with "ui/" e.g. "ui/button", "ui/elements/button"
matches two components: bar and foo
matches all components of the scope "my-scope.org"

[MissingPackagesDependenciesOnFs, MissingManuallyConfiguredPackages, UntrackedDependencies, ResolveErrors, RelativeComponents, RelativeComponentsAuthored, ParseErrors, MissingDists, LegacyInsideHarmony, MissingDependenciesOnFs, ImportNonMainFiles, MultipleEnvs, MissingLinksFromNodeModulesToSrc, CircularDependencies, DuplicateComponentAndPackage, MergeConfigHasConflict, NonLoadedEnv, ExternalEnvWithoutVersion, RemovedDependencies, RemovedEnv, DeprecatedDependencies, SelfReference, ImportFromDirectory]

by default, only new and modified components are built.
the build takes place in an isolated directories on the filesystem (called "capsules"). the component files are copied to these directories
and the package-manager installs the dependencies in the capsules root. once done, the build pipeline is running.
because this process can take a while on a large workspace, some flags are available to shorten the process. See the example section for more info.

description: switch between component versions or remove local changes
extendedDescription:
`bit checkout <version> [component-pattern]` => checkout the specified ids (or all components when --all is used) to the specified version
`bit checkout head [component-pattern]` => checkout to the last snap/tag (use --latest if you only want semver tags), omit [component-pattern] to checkout head for all
`bit checkout head~x [component-pattern]` => go backward x generations from the head and checkout to that version
`bit checkout latest [component-pattern]` => checkout to the latest satisfying semver tag, omit [component-pattern] to checkout latest for all
`bit checkout reset [component-pattern]` => remove local modifications from the specified ids (or all components when --all is used). also, if a component dir is deleted from the filesystem, it'll be restored
when on a lane, "checkout head" only checks out components on this lane. to update main components, run "bit lane merge main"

revert is similar to "lane checkout", but it keeps the versions and only change the files.

commands.name: merge <lane> [pattern]
options: same as "--auto-merge-resolve manual". in case of merge conflict, write the files with the conflict markers
in case of a merge conflict, resolve according to the provided strategy: [ours, theirs, manual]
DEPRECATED. use --auto-merge-resolve. in case of a conflict, keep local modifications
DEPRECATED. use --auto-merge-resolve. in case of a conflict, override local with incoming changes
merge only lane components that are in the current workspace
do not auto snap after merge completed without conflicts of diverged components (see command description)
do not pass snaps from the other lane even for non-diverged components (see command description)
auto-tag all lane components after merging into main (or tag-merge in case of snap-merge)
in case of snap during the merge, run the build-pipeline (similar to bit snap --build)
relevant for --build, to allow build to succeed even if tasks like tests or lint fail
override the default message for the auto snap
skip deleting the lane readme component after merging
relevant for merging lanes into main, which by default squashes all lane snaps
relevant for merging a lane into another non-main lane, which by default does not squash
allow merging when components are modified due to config changes (such as dependencies) only and not files
display detailed information about components that were legitimately unmerged
do not install dependencies of the imported components
use the local state of target-lane if exits locally, without updating it from the remote
relevant for "pattern" and "--workspace". merge also dependencies of the specified components
relevant when a component on a lane and the component on main have nothing in common. merge-strategy can be "ours" (default) or "theirs"
DEPRECATED (this is now the default). when merging main, include workspace components that are not on the lane (by default only lane components are merged)
when merging main into a lane, exclude workspace components that are not on the lane (by default all workspace components are merged)
UNSUPPORTED YET. for each component, find the divergent point from main and merge to that point. do not change the head
commands.description: merge a local or a remote lane to the current lane
commands.extendedDescription:
by default, the provided lane will be fetched from the remote before merging.
to merge the lane from the local scope without updating it first, use "--skip-fetch" flag.

when the current and merge candidate lanes are diverged in history and the files could be merged with no conflicts,
these components will be snap-merged to complete the merge. use "no-auto-snap" to opt-out, or "tag" to tag instead.

when the components are not diverged in history, and the current lane is behind the merge candidate, the merge will
simply update the components and the heads according to the merge candidate.
to opt-out, use "--no-snap", the components will be written as the merge candidate, and will be left as modified.

in case a component in both ends don't share history (no snap is found in common), the merge will require "--resolve-unrelated" flag.
this flag keeps the history of one end and saves a reference to the other end. the decision of which end to keep is determined by the following:
1. if the component exists on main, then the history linked to main will be kept.
in this case, the strategy of "--resolve-unrelated" only determines which source-code to keep. it's not about the history.
2. if the component doesn't exist on main, then by default, the history of the current lane will be kept.
unless "--resolve-unrelated" is set to "theirs", in which case the history of the other lane will be kept.
2. a. an edge case: if the component is deleted on the current lane, the strategy will always be "theirs".
so then the history (and the source-code) of the other lane will be kept.

partially merge the lane - only components that match the specified component-pattern
Component pattern format: component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
wrap the pattern with quotes. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button".
use '$' prefix to filter by states/attributes, e.g. '$deprecated', '$modified' or '$env:teambit.react/react'.

commands.name: merge-move <new-lane-name>
options: remote scope to which this lane will be exported, default to the workspace.json's defaultScope (can be changed up to first export of the lane with "bit lane change-scope")
commands.description: EXPERIMENT. move the current merge state into a new lane. the current lane will be reset
commands.extendedDescription:
this command is useful when you got a messy merge state that from one hand you don't want
to loose the changes, but on the other hand, you want to keep your lane without those changes.
this command does the following:
1. create a new lane with the current merge state. including all the filesystem changes. (in practice, it leaves the fs intact)
2. reset the current lane to the state before the merge. so then once done with the new lane, you can switch to the current lane and it'll be clean.

description: clears Bit's cache from current working machine
extendedDescription:
The following gets removed by this command:
1) components cache on the filesystem (mainly the dependencies graph and docs)
2) scope's index file, which maps the component-id:object-hash

name: rename <current-name> <new-name>
options: define the scope for the new component
update the import/require statements in all dependent components (in the same workspace)
avoid renaming files and variables/classes according to the new component name
use ast to transform files instead of regex
DEPRECATED. this is now the default
instead of deleting the original component, deprecating it
relative path in the workspace to place new component in. by default, the directory of the new component is from your workspace's "defaultScope" value
description: rename component. if exported, create a new component and delete the original component. otherwise just renames current component

arguments.name: current-name
arguments.description: the current component name (without its scope name)

arguments.name: new-name
arguments.description: the new component name (without its scope name. use --scope to define the new component's scope)

name: fork <source-component-id> [target-component-name]
options: default scope for the new component
relative path in the workspace for the new component. by default the path is `<scope>/<namespace>/<name>`
update the import/require statements in all dependent components (in the same workspace)
do not install packages of the imported components
set the environment for the new component
do not copy the config (aspects-config, env, etc) to the new component. helpful when it fails during aspect loading
avoid refactoring file and variable/class names according to the new component name
avoid saving a reference to the original component
use ast to transform files instead of regex
description: create a new component forked from an existing one (copies source files and configs)

arguments.name: source-component-id
arguments.description: the component id of the source component

arguments.name: target-component-name
arguments.description: the name for the new component (component name without scope, e.g. name/spaces/my-button). to set a different scope, use the '--scope' flag

name: check-types [component-pattern]
options: check-types for all components, not only modified and new
in case issues found, exit with code 1
return the output in json format
description: check typescript types

arguments.name: component-pattern
arguments.description:
component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
wrap the pattern with quotes. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button".
use '$' prefix to filter by states/attributes, e.g. '$deprecated', '$modified' or '$env:teambit.react/react'.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

name: aspect <sub-command>
description: manage aspects

commands.name: list [pattern]
options: show the origins where the aspects were taken from
commands.description: list all aspects configured on component(s)

arguments.description:

wrap the pattern with quotes. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button".

arguments.description:

commands.name: get <component-name>
options: show the origins where the aspects were taken from
commands.description: list the aspects set on a component, as well as their configs and data

arguments.name: component-name
arguments.description: the component name or component id to fetch aspects for

commands.name: set <pattern> <aspect-id> [config]
options: merge with an existing config if exits. (by default, it replaces overlapping existing configs)
commands.description: set components with an aspect to extend their development tools, metadata and (possibly) artifacts

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.description:
the components to extend. component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
wrap the pattern with quotes. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button".
use '$' prefix to filter by states/attributes, e.g. '$deprecated', '$modified' or '$env:teambit.react/react'.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

arguments.name: aspect-id
arguments.description: the aspect's component id

arguments.name: config
arguments.description: the aspect config. enter the config as a stringified JSON (e.g. '{"foo":"bar"}' ). when no config is provided, an aspect is set with an empty config ({}).

commands.name: unset <pattern> <aspect-id>
commands.description: unset an aspect from component(s).

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.description:
the components to target. component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
wrap the pattern with quotes. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button".
use '$' prefix to filter by states/attributes, e.g. '$deprecated', '$modified' or '$env:teambit.react/react'.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

arguments.name: aspect-id
arguments.description: the aspect's component id

commands.name: update <aspect-id> [pattern]
commands.description: update a version of an aspect for all or specified components

arguments.name: aspect-id
arguments.description: the aspect's component id. optionally, add a version (id@version), otherwise will use the latest version from the remote

arguments.name: pattern
arguments.description:
the components to update (defaults to all components). component name, component id, or component pattern. use component pattern to select multiple components.
wrap the pattern with quotes. use comma to separate patterns and "!" to exclude. e.g. "ui/**, !ui/button".
use '$' prefix to filter by states/attributes, e.g. '$deprecated', '$modified' or '$env:teambit.react/react'.
use `bit pattern --help` to understand patterns better and `bit pattern <pattern>` to validate the pattern.

examples.description: update all components with the "ui" namespace that use scope.org/aspect, to use its latest version
update version of scope.org/aspect to version 2.0.0 for all components configured with that aspect.
